In this verse, Allah shows how reckless the disbelievers were when they said to the Prophet Muhammad and the Muslims with a defiant attitude, "When will the promised punishment of the Hereafter come? If the threat is true, then show it to us now!"

They asked for Allah's punishment to be brought upon them immediately. This statement shows that they did not believe at all in the existence of that punishment. Consequently, they also did not believe in the Day of Judgment, nor in Allah's power to reckon and recompense human deeds.
text.40:
In this verse, Allah explains that if the disbelievers knew that they would be powerless to escape the torment of hellfire that would engulf them from all directions, they would certainly not say such things. Therefore, their challenge to hasten the coming of the torment upon them truly arises from their ignorance and denial, because they close themselves off from the true teachings conveyed by the Messenger of Allah.

The existence of torment and the Day of Judgment that comes suddenly should serve as a warning for those who believe in Allah and to remain focused on the practice of religion, as Allah says:

Therefore, set your face toward the correct religion before there comes from Allah a Day which cannot be averted. That Day, they will be divided. (ar-Rum/30: 43)
text.41:
In this verse, Allah affirms that the torment of the Hereafter, which is threatened upon the disbelievers, will certainly occur. It will even come upon them suddenly and unexpectedly, causing them to panic and be unable to save themselves. And they will truly not be given any respite or opportunity to prepare themselves to escape from it.

At the end of this verse, Allah provides comfort to Prophet Muhammad, who was constantly mocked by the disbelievers. Allah affirms that he is not the only one who has been mocked by the disbelievers. Indeed, all the messengers whom Allah sent before him were also targets of their people's mockery. However, the torment that they used to ridicule eventually came upon them. And no one could save them from the terrible torment.
text.42:
With this verse, Allah commands the Prophet to answer their mockery by posing a question to them: who can guard and protect them from Allah's punishment, whether at night or during the day?

The question is intended to make them realize that no one has the power to protect them from Allah's torment and punishment, because He is All-Powerful to do whatever He wills. If they always remembered Allah's *iradah* (will) and power, they would not mock or challenge in such a way. However, because they are people who have turned away from remembering Allah and His power, that is why they mock His Messenger and challenge with an arrogant attitude that the punishment be inflicted upon them immediately.
text.43:
This verse is a continuation of the previous verse, where Allah commands His Messenger to pose a question to the disbelievers, to make them aware of Allah's power. The content of the question mentioned in this verse is, "Do they have gods that can protect them from Allah's punishment?" The gods they worship are certainly unable to help them, unable even to help themselves. At the end of this verse, Allah reaffirms that the gods they worship will not escape Allah's punishment. If that is the case, how will they be able to protect their worshippers?

Thus, this verse presents two kinds of weaknesses of the gods worshipped by the disbelievers, which make them unworthy of being worshipped and deified. First, they are unable to help themselves. Second, they themselves cannot escape Allah's punishment. Thus, their condition is weaker than their worshippers.

With these two realities, they should be able to conclude that the objects they worship have no ability whatsoever to protect them from Allah's punishment.
text.44:
This verse explains that Allah bestows the pleasures of life and wealth upon the disbelievers, allowing them to live comfortably with long lives. However, Muslims should not be envious or dazzled by their worldly pleasures, because all that wealth and luxury is given to them by Allah as a test. If that wealth causes their hearts to become arrogant, and their nature to become harsh, leading them to evil deeds, all of this will cause their sins to increase, and the punishment they will receive will become more severe.

Thus, it can be understood that Allah gives them luxury and the pleasures of life not because Allah is unable to send down punishment upon them, but on the contrary, that luxury is a test for them that can lead them to destruction, both outwardly and inwardly, as well as a painful punishment.

This verse also mentions another form of loss that Allah inflicts upon them, namely the decrease in the number of their followers because many have embraced Islam. As a result, their territory also diminishes because the religion of Islam has spread to areas that were originally part of their territory. With the decline in the number of followers and their territory, their strength also decreases.

After describing their condition, which has become fragile due to luxury, and weakened due to the decrease in the number of followers and their power, Allah, at the end of the verse, poses a question: in such a state, who can achieve victory, do they still have hope?

Of course, they will not achieve victory. Besides their fragile and weak state, Allah's power is absolute over His servants, and Allah does what He wills. Nothing can overcome Him.
text.45:
In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to affirm to the disbelievers and polytheists his primary duty as a Messenger, which is simply to convey Allah's warning to them through revelation, namely the Qur'an, and to explain to them the consequences of their disbelief by relating stories about past nations. As for the reckoning and retribution for their deeds, that is within Allah's power, not the Messenger's.

This verse also contains a subtle rebuke to the disbelievers, that they are like deaf people, not listening to or paying attention to the warnings conveyed to them. Their hearts are as if they have been sealed, and they do not accept the truth and guidance of Allah that the Messenger conveys to them. This is a sign of those who deny God, as Allah says:

"(They are) deaf, dumb and blind, so they do not understand." (al-Baqarah/2: 171)
text.46:
Allah explains in this verse one of the characteristics of the disbelievers, which is that when they are afflicted by Allah's punishment, even if it is only a little, they complain and regret, saying, "Alas, woe to us, indeed we have been wrongdoers."

Before the punishment comes to afflict them, they do not believe in it, they even challenge it to be brought upon them immediately, due to their denial and arrogance. But after the punishment comes to afflict them, only then do they know about Allah's power, so regret arises in their hearts.
text.47:
In this verse, Allah firmly states that in judging the deeds of His servants on the Day of Judgment, Allah will establish scales of justice that are truly just, so that no one will be harmed in that assessment.

This means that the assessment will be carried out with the utmost precision, so that not a single servant will have their good deeds reduced in the slightest, causing their reward to be diminished from what they should rightfully receive. Conversely, none of them will have their evil deeds exaggerated, causing them to receive a heavier punishment than they deserve, even though Allah is capable of doing so.

As for giving rewards that are multiplied from the amount of their good deeds or inflicting punishment that is lighter than their evil deeds, that is up to Allah's will, and Allah is the Most Gracious and Most Merciful.

In Allah's justice, it is explained that all of humanity's good deeds, no matter how small, will certainly be rewarded by Him, and all of their evil deeds, no matter how small, will certainly be repaid with His punishment or torment. In this regard, Allah says in another verse:

"So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it, And whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it." (az-Zilzal/99: 7-8)

Current technological capabilities have been able to meticulously record all events and store them for a long time, let alone Allah's capabilities.

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that He is sufficient as a witness and the most just Reckoner. This is a guarantee that the assessment that will be carried out on all the deeds of His servants will be done by Him on the Day of Reckoning with the fairest assessment, so that not a single servant will be harmed or oppressed when receiving rewards for their good deeds or receiving punishment for the evil deeds they have committed.
text.48:
This verse explains that Allah revealed the Torah to the Prophets Musa and Harun. The Torah is a source of enlightenment and guidance for those who are pious and fear Allah. The Torah is also called al-Furqan, just like the Qur'an, because the Torah also contains sharia, namely laws and regulations that distinguish between right and wrong, between good and evil legally, so that every human behavior and action, whether good or bad, is explained in terms of its legal consequences or sanctions. This is not the case with the Gospel (Injil) revealed to Prophet Isa (peace be upon him). He did not bring sharia.

At the end of the verse, it is emphasized that the Torah, which functions as a bearer of sharia, and as a light of guidance and warning, is only useful for those who are pious. This means that the Torah is not a guidance for those who are not pious, namely those who are unwilling to carry out Allah's commands and avoid His prohibitions. For them, a severe punishment is prepared, because they deny Allah's guidance.
text.49:
Furthermore, in this verse, Allah explains the characteristics of the righteous (muttaqin), namely: First, they are constantly fearful of Allah's punishment, even though that punishment is one of the unseen (ghaib) things. Second, the righteous people mentioned in this verse are those who are constantly afraid of the coming of the Day of Judgment, striving to prepare themselves to face the things that will happen on the Day of Judgment, including the Day of Reckoning and the Day of Recompense.

Because of their fear of Allah's punishment on the Day of Judgment that will befall those who are not righteous, these righteous people always guard themselves against things and actions that lead to sin and punishment. Therefore, they always carry out Allah's commands and avoid all His prohibitions.
text.50:
In this verse, Allah directs attention to the Qur'an that He revealed to His final Prophet and Messenger. Allah affirms that the Qur'an is a reminder and a very beneficial lesson for those who are pious, so it is fitting that its commands and prohibitions are followed and used as a guide in navigating the path of life.

At the end of this verse, Allah rebukes the attitude of those who still deny the Qur'an, even though they have no reason whatsoever to deny it. Indeed, the Qur'an only provides lessons and guidance that are beneficial for those who want to follow it. Moreover, the goodness and benefits of the Qur'an have already been explained to them.
text.51:
In this verse, it is explained that Allah has sent Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham), peace be upon him, and He has bestowed guidance upon him and made him a leader of his people in achieving salvation in this world and the hereafter. With this guidance, he was able to save himself and his people from misguided beliefs and from worshiping other than Allah, such as statues and idols.

At the end of this verse, it is emphasized that Allah truly knows the affairs of Ibrahim, both before he was sent as a messenger and afterwards. This means that Allah knows his personality, character, and morals well. Ibrahim was a person who adhered to the belief in the oneness of Allah, without being mixed with any polytheism, and he also possessed noble qualities and morals, so it was fitting that he was chosen and appointed as a prophet and messenger.

Most commentators (mufasir) say that Allah gave the guidance of truth to Ibrahim even before he was appointed as a Messenger, so that with that guidance he could observe the universe until he came to the conviction about the existence of Allah, the One and Only. Therefore, his struggle in eradicating polytheism in the form of worshiping statues and idols among his people was carried out before he was appointed as a messenger.

As an explanation, it is appropriate to explain here that according to history, Prophet Ibrahim came from Ur al-Kaldaniyah (Ur of Chaldea), the capital of the Chaldean Kingdom in Southern Mesopotamia. The Chaldean Kingdom was ruled by a king named Namruz, who ruled in 2300 BC, before the reign of Hammurabi, who ruled in 2000 BC. King Namruz was known as a very cruel king who claimed to be a god. The Chaldeans, in addition to worshiping gods in the form of statues, were also ordered to worship Namruz.

It was King Namruz who ordered the burning of Prophet Ibrahim. Finally, Prophet Ibrahim, along with his wife Sarah and his brother Lut (Lot), left the city of Ur, migrated to Harran, and then to Palestine.

At one point, there was a famine in Palestine, so Ibrahim, along with his wife and Lut, along with his wife, went to Egypt. In Egypt, Ibrahim met Pharaoh. Pharaoh gave them gifts, among which was a woman named Hajar (Hagar) for Sarah, Ibrahim's wife. After returning to Palestine, Lut separated and went to Sodom, a city near the Dead Sea in Jordan.

Because Sarah and Ibrahim did not yet have a son, Hajar was given by Sarah to Prophet Ibrahim to be his wife. With Hajar, Ibrahim had a son, namely Ismail (Ishmael). Then, Ibrahim moved Siti Hajar and Ismail to Mecca. In Mecca, Prophet Ibrahim rebuilt the Ka'bah, and Ismail resided in Mecca.

In his old age, Prophet Ibrahim was blessed with another son from his first wife Sarah, namely Ishak (Isaac). Prophet Ibrahim died and was buried in Hebron, the place where Sarah had been buried earlier. From the descendants of Ibrahim, peace be upon him, there were many prophets, imams, righteous people, and leaders who called to the religion of Allah.
text.52:
This verse explains that Allah bestowed guidance upon Ibrahim, so he questioned his father Azar, who was gathered with his people, about the idols they made and worshipped with diligence.

The question implied that Azar and his people should use their intellect to contemplate that these objects were not worthy of worship, because they did not possess the attributes of a God worthy of worship. They worshipped created things, not the Creator, and could not bring benefit to themselves, let alone to others. They refused to worship Allah, even though Allah is the Creator, Sustainer, Educator, Protector, and Ruler of all creatures. If they were willing to think about it, they would not do such a thing. So, they were actually people who did not want to use the intellect that Allah had bestowed upon them.
text.53:
In this verse, it is explained that Azar and his people answered Ibrahim's question with the statement that their worship of idols was merely following the actions of their ancestors. This answer reveals several weaknesses. First, they were unable to answer Ibrahim's question using reasonable arguments based on truth. Second, their religious life was based solely on *ta'ashshub* (fanaticism) towards the traditions of their ancestors, not on sound belief and thought. Third, they closed themselves off to things different from their customs, even if the truth was evident. It was as if their ears were blocked, and their hearts were tightly sealed.

The attitude of *ta'ashshub* (fanaticism) and blind *taqlid* is characteristic of people who are unable to defend their principles with true evidence and strong *hujjah*, because the principles they adhere to are indeed not true. They adhere to them merely to maintain the traditions they inherited from their ancestors. This attitude greatly hinders human progress and plunges them into denial of the truth, even leading to disbelief in Allah.

Among Muslims, we find people who blindly follow one *mazhab*, or a particular *imam*, so that they refuse to accept the truth that comes from others. Such an attitude is contrary to the teachings of Islam, which always encourages people to use their minds in seeking the truth.

The *imams* of various Islamic *fiqh mazhabs* forbade their followers from blindly following them and encouraged them to be open to accepting the opinions of others if it turned out that those opinions were more correct than the opinions they held.
text.54: This verse explains that Abraham responded to their answer by pointing out the evil of their ancestors' actions in worshipping other than Allah. Abraham said to his father and his people that they were all in error because they worshipped idols and statues. By doing so, they had strayed far from the truth and deviated from the right path. They did not adhere to the true religion and common sense. What they held onto was only the desire of their lusts and the whispers of Satan.
text.55:
This verse mentions the response of Azar and his people to Abraham, which was whether Abraham came to them with the truth, or was merely mocking them.

From their words, several questions can be inferred regarding their attitude. First, after hearing Abraham's words which demeaned the status of their gods and declared their actions as misguided, their hearts began to stir, because such words had never been heard among them. Second, seeing Abraham's serious and firm attitude in his speech, their hearts began to doubt the truth and their own actions as idol worshippers. Third, they asked Abraham to provide evidence and reasons that would demonstrate the truth of Abraham's words to them. Fourth, if Abraham could not provide such evidence, then they considered Abraham to be merely mocking them.
text.56:
This verse explains that after Abraham understood the reality mentioned above, he responded to their answer with words that no longer exposed their error in worshipping statues and idols. Instead, he turned to explaining the truth and mentioning the God who truly deserves to be worshipped. So, Abraham explained to them that he came bringing the truth, not mocking, that their Lord is the Lord of the Heavens and the Earth. He is the One who deserves to be worshipped, because He is the One who created the heavens and the earth and created themselves, and gives His grace and protection to all His creatures, because He is All-Powerful and Most Merciful.

Thus, they would realize that worshipping Allah is the correct action, while worshipping statues and idols is a great error.

At the end of this verse, it is explained that to strengthen their belief in the creed of *tawhid* (monotheism), Abraham reviewed his previous statement by affirming that he is capable and fully responsible for providing evidence for the truth of what he conveyed to them. This explanation is intended to eliminate their suspicion that Abraham was only mocking them with the aforementioned statements.
text.57: This verse explains what was contained in the heart of Ibrahim, which was spoken and heard by some of his people, namely that he was determined to destroy the idols that were worshiped by his people, when they had left the place.
text.58: In this verse, it is mentioned that Ibrahim's resolve to use the grand celebration to destroy the idols was indeed carried out. So, after his people had left, he destroyed the idols until they were shattered into pieces, except for the largest idol. He did not destroy this one, because he hoped that when they returned there and asked him about who had destroyed the other idols, he would tell them to ask the largest idol, which of course would not be able to answer their question.
text.59:
This verse explains that what Ibrahim expected actually happened. After hearing the news that their idols had been damaged, they came back to that place and asked Ibrahim, "Who has done this evil deed to our gods? Indeed, he is truly one of the wrongdoers."

From this statement, we can understand that until that moment they had still not fully accepted what Ibrahim conveyed to them, and they still worshipped and glorified those idols, and still referred to them as their gods. This aroused anger towards the one who destroyed them.
text.60:
Allah explains in this verse that those who were near the worship of idols answered the question above by saying that they heard a young man named Ibrahim had destroyed the idols.

From this, we understand that at that time Ibrahim was still a young man (approximately 16 years old), and had not yet been sent by Allah as His Prophet and Messenger. Therefore, his actions in destroying the idols were not in the context of his duty as a Messenger, but rather arose from the impulse of his belief in Allah, based on the guidance to the truth that Allah had bestowed upon him, before he was appointed as a Messenger.
text.61:
This verse explains that after they received the answer that a young man named Ibrahim had destroyed the idols, they ordered that the young man be brought before the people, hoping that someone else had witnessed the young man committing the destruction, so that the testimony could be used as evidence.

This gives the understanding that among them at that time, a rule was already in place that they would not take direct action against someone who was accused before there was evidence, whether in the form of testimony from someone, or in the form of a confession from the accused.
text.62: In this verse, it is explained that after they brought Ibrahim before the people, they conducted an investigation and examination of him by asking questions, whether it was true that he had committed the destruction of the idols. They asked this question with the hope that Ibrahim would admit that he was the one who had committed the destruction. They would use this confession as a reason to punish Ibrahim.
text.63:
This verse explains Ibrahim's response to the accusation. Ibrahim's answer turned out to be very surprising to them, because it did not meet their expectations, because Ibrahim did not admit that he had committed the destruction, but he said that the one who destroyed the idols was actually the largest idol that was still intact.

Ibrahim intended such an answer to achieve his goal, which was to make his people realize that the idols were not worthy of worship, because they could not do anything. Especially to defend themselves.

It is clear that his people would not believe that the largest idol was the one who destroyed the other idols. Because they realized that this was impossible, because an idol cannot do anything, because it is an inanimate object. If they had realized this, they should have stopped worshiping idols.

At the end of this verse, Ibrahim's next statement to his people is mentioned, telling them to ask the idols themselves who had destroyed them.

This statement caused his people to become even more cornered, because if they asked the idols, they would certainly not get an answer, because the idols did not hear and could not speak. If that is the case, are the idols worthy of worship? If there are still people who worship them, surely that person is not using their sound mind.
text.64:
This verse explains Ibrahim's answer to the accusation. Ibrahim's answer turned out to be very surprising to them, because it did not meet their expectations, because Ibrahim did not admit that he had committed the destruction, but he said that the one who had destroyed the idols was actually the largest statue that was still intact.

Ibrahim intended such an answer to achieve his goal, which was to make his people realize that the idols were not worthy of worship, because they could not do anything. Especially to defend themselves.

It is clear that his people would not believe that the largest statue was the one who destroyed the other statues. Because they realized that it was impossible for that to happen, because a statue cannot do anything, because it is an inanimate object. If they had realized this, they should have stopped worshiping idols.

At the end of this verse, Ibrahim's next statement to his people is mentioned, telling them to ask the idols themselves who had damaged them.

This statement caused his people to be even more cornered, because if they asked the idols, they would certainly not get an answer, because the idols do not hear and cannot speak. If that is the case, are the idols worthy of worship? If there are still people who worship them, surely that person is not using their sound mind.
text.65:
This verse explains their condition after regretting their mistakes and foolishness. They then lowered their heads and remained silent. At that moment, Satan returned to tempt them, so that their awareness, which had initially begun to sprout, disappeared, and they returned to their original beliefs, wanting to defend the idols that were their faith. Therefore, they then said to Ibrahim, "Why did Ibrahim tell them to ask these idols, even though he already knew that the idols could not speak?"

This statement is an admission that they also knew that the idols could not hear, think, or speak, but they still worshipped and deified them.
text.66: Allah explains in this verse that after they acknowledged that the idols could not hear, think, or speak, Ibrahim immediately responded by saying why they worshipped something other than Allah that could not provide any benefit whatsoever, nor could it bring harm to them, and it could not even speak or defend itself.
text.67:
This verse mentions the continuation of Ibrahim's words to them, that they would be doomed along with the idols they worshipped besides Allah. Did they not understand the evil and error of their actions?

That statement had truly cornered the idol worshippers, and ignited their immense anger.

66-67. Responding to that statement, He, Ibrahim, said in front of the dignitaries of the City of Ur, Chaldea, Babylon, Southern Mesopotamia, "Why do you all worship gods besides Allah, worshipping something that cannot provide the slightest benefit by worshipping it, nor bring harm to you by not worshipping it?" Ibrahim then affirmed his response, "Woe to you and what you worship besides Allah in this world and the Hereafter! Do you not think, will you continue to worship those idols or stop?"
text.68:
This verse explains that after they ran out of wit and reasons to answer Ibrahim's (Abraham's) words, and their anger peaked, they agreed to burn Ibrahim and defend their gods, if they truly wanted revenge.

Thus, they decided to destroy Ibrahim, an action they considered the best way to defend the honor of their gods and to eliminate the obstacles preventing them from worshiping idols. They chose the most cruel way to destroy Ibrahim, which was to burn him in a bonfire. In this way, Ibrahim could be eliminated, so that they could achieve victory for their self-esteem and their gods.
text.69:
In this verse, Allah's action to protect and help Ibrahim from the cruelty of his people is explained, namely burning Ibrahim in a blazing fire.

As is known, Allah has given certain characteristics to each of His creatures. That characteristic remains valid for it as the Sunnah of Allah in the world. Among them is fire, which is hot and burning, so that even very strong metals can be melted by fire, let alone the human body. So Allah protected Ibrahim from the heat of the fire by removing the heat and burning properties from the burning fire, so that Ibrahim did not feel hot when burned and was not burned in the blazing bonfire.

Allah says, "O fire, be coolness and safety upon Ibrahim." With Allah's command to the fire, its nature changed from hot to cold, and it did not harm Ibrahim until the fire went out. This adds to the proof of Allah's power, which the disbelievers should realize.

In a hadith narrated by al-Bukhari from Ibn 'Abbas, it is mentioned that when Prophet Ibrahim was thrown into the fire, he recited:

"Sufficient for us is Allah, and [He is] the best Disposer of affairs." (Riwayat al-Bukhari)

Such is the help and protection that Allah usually gives to the prophets, saints, and His righteous servants. Although at that time Ibrahim was not yet a prophet or messenger, he was still a righteous servant of Allah.

It is worth remembering that Prophet Muhammad also experienced plots from the disbelieving Quraysh who tried to destroy him, such as the events before and after the Hijrah. However, even though they had made neat plans to achieve a specific purpose, their implementation did not bring the results they expected, because Allah had given His help and protection to His Messenger, as the fulfillment of His promise:

And Allah will protect you from the people. (al-Ma'idah/5: 67)
text.70:
Allah affirms in this verse that the schemes carried out by the polytheists against the prophets to destroy them had the opposite effect, namely, causing them to be the ones who suffered the greatest loss.

With their words and deeds, they wanted to extinguish the light of truth conveyed by Ibrahim, by lighting a bonfire to destroy him. But in the end, the fire they lit was extinguished without leaving any trace on Ibrahim a.s., thanks to the protection of Allah the Almighty. This clearly demonstrates the falsehood of the beliefs they held and the evil of the methods they employed to achieve victory. Conversely, Ibrahim was on the side of truth, because he conveyed Allah's guidance to eradicate falsehood and injustice.
text.71:
In this verse, it is explained that Allah completed His blessings upon Ibrahim. Allah saved him from the raging fire. History states that Allah saved him from the evil of the inhabitants of the city of Ur in Southern Mesopotamia, which was his homeland, then he migrated to the land of Harran, then to Palestine in the region of Syam.

In this verse, it is mentioned that the land of Syam is a land that Allah has blessed abundantly for all mankind. Thus, the land is very fertile, with plenty of water and vegetation, providing many benefits to its inhabitants. In addition, the land is also the birthplace of prophets who brought the light of guidance to mankind. Baitul Makdis, located in Palestine, is also part of the Syam region, and the first Qibla for Muslims.

In this verse, it is explained that Prophet Lut also migrated together to the land of Syam. According to historical accounts, Prophet Lut was the son of Ibrahim a.s.'s brother.
text.72: In this verse, Allah mentions another of His blessings upon Ibrahim (peace be upon him) in addition to His previous blessings, which is that Allah bestowed upon him a son, Isaac, while Jacob was the son of Isaac, thus a grandson of Ibrahim who gave birth to the descendants of the Children of Israel (Bani Israil). Besides that, Ibrahim also had another son, namely Ismail, from Siti Hajar. Allah made all of them, namely Ibrahim, Ismail, Isaac, and Jacob, as prophets and righteous people.
text.73:
In this verse, Allah mentions an additional favor to Ibrahim, besides the favor that has been explained in the previous verse, namely that Ibrahim's descendants are not only righteous people, but also imams or leaders of the ummah who invite people to accept and practice the religion of Allah, and invite them to good and beneficial deeds, based on Allah's command and permission.

The Prophet Ibrahim, who was given the title "Khalilullah" (Friend of God), is also the father of several prophets because many of the prophets who came after him were from his descendants, up to the last Prophet and Messenger, namely Muhammad saw, who is among the grandchildren of Ibrahim a.s. through the Prophet Ismail. They received Allah's revelation containing teachings and guidance towards various virtues, especially obeying Allah's commands and abandoning His prohibitions.

In addition, Allah also revealed to them to establish prayer (salat) and pay zakat. These two types of worship are mentioned by Allah specifically, because the worship of salat has the distinction of being both a physical worship and a means of strengthening the relationship between the servant and his Lord, while zakat has the distinction of being the most important form of wealth worship that strengthens relationships with fellow servants, especially when remembering that wealth is very important in human life.

These two types of worship, although they must be complemented by other forms of worship, reflect two main qualities in humans, namely obedience to Allah and compassion for fellow human beings.

Finally, at the end of this verse, Allah explains that the descendants of the Prophet Ibrahim are people who worship Allah alone with full of humility and submission (khusyuk and tawadu).
text.74:
In this verse, Allah explains three kinds of blessings bestowed upon Prophet Lut:

First, Prophet Lut was granted wisdom and sagacity in giving judgments or punishments, so that with it he could provide good solutions and decisions in matters that occurred among his people.

Second, he was also granted very useful knowledge, especially religious knowledge, so that he could know and carry out his obligations to Allah and to his fellow creatures well. These two conditions are very important for those who will be sent by Allah as His Prophets and Messengers.

Third, he was saved by Allah when the land where he lived, namely Sodom, was struck by Allah's punishment because its inhabitants committed many evils and atrocities openly. Among the vile acts they committed were engaging in sexual relations between men (homosexuality), disrupting commercial traffic by robbing merchandise, disobeying Lut and disregarding Allah's warnings, and others. So the city of Sodom was destroyed by Allah. Prophet Lut and his family were saved by Allah except for his wife who also disobeyed Allah.

At the end of this verse, Allah explains why the people of Lut committed such evil and vile acts, namely because they had become evil and wicked people, no longer heeding Allah's laws, and liked to do forbidden things, so that they wallowed in sinful deeds and indecent words, all of which they did openly, without shame.
text.75:
In this verse, Allah explains His mercy upon Prophet Lut (peace be upon him), by including him within the encompassment of His mercy. The meaning is that Prophet Lut was among those whom Allah loved and cherished, so that he became one of the inhabitants of His Paradise.

Allah says to Paradise, "You are My mercy, through you I show mercy to whomever I will among My servants." (Narrated by al-Bukhari)

Finally, at the end of this verse, Allah explains the reason why He bestowed such great mercy upon Prophet Lut, which is because he was included in the group of Allah's righteous servants who always obeyed Allah's commands and prohibitions.
text.76:
With this verse, Allah reminds the Messenger of Allah (Muhammad) and the Muslims of the story of Prophet Noah (Nuh) a.s., who is referred to as the second father of mankind. Long before Prophet Muhammad, even before Prophets Abraham (Ibrahim) and Lot (Lut), Prophet Noah had been sent by Allah as His Messenger. Because of the extreme denial of his people, so that they did not heed his call to the religion of Allah, he finally prayed to God:

"And Noah said, "My Lord, do not leave upon the earth from among the disbelievers an inhabitant." (Nuh/71: 26)

And his prayer again:

"So I invoked my Lord, "Indeed, I am overcome, so help (me)." (al-Qamar/54: 10)

However, these prayers were uttered after 950 years of him carrying out his da'wah (propagation of faith), yet his people still denied and did not heed his call to the religion of Allah.

According to narration, Prophet Noah a.s. was sent by Allah to be His Messenger when he was 40 years old. After the occurrence of Allah's punishment in the form of a hurricane and a great flood, Prophet Noah still lived for 40 years. Thus, it is estimated that his age reached Â±1050 years.

In this verse, Allah explains that after Noah a.s. uttered these prayers, Allah granted them, namely by inflicting a very terrible flood, so that the sea water overflowed high and destroyed the country along with the unbelievers.

As for Prophet Noah and his family, except for his disobedient wife and son, and his believing people, Allah saved them from that terrible disaster, namely with a large boat that Prophet Noah made before the flood occurred, upon the command and guidance of Allah.
text.77:
This verse affirms that Allah has sent help to Prophet Noah and his believing followers against the evil of those who denied His verses and did not accept the proofs and explanations conveyed by His Messenger.

At the end of this verse, Allah explains the reason why He helped Prophet Noah so that the disbelieving people were destroyed by a terrible torment, namely because of the evil of his people such as shirk, both in their words and deeds. Disobeying Allah and violating His commands were the evil deeds of his people from generation to generation. Therefore, it was fitting that they received retribution from Allah.

The stories presented in the Qur'an should be a lesson for mankind, after the sending of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), to all of mankind. Allah says:

"So take warning, O you with vision." (al-Hasyr/59:2)
text.78:
In this verse, Allah explains the situation of David and Solomon when they gave judgment in a matter that occurred between their people.

In a narration from Ibn Abbas quoted from the Tafsir of Ibn Kathir, it is mentioned that a group of sheep had damaged a farmer's crops at night, leading to a dispute between the owner of the crops and the owner of the sheep. They then came to David (peace be upon him) to seek judgment. After conducting an examination, David (peace be upon him) ruled that the sheep should be handed over to the owner of the crops, as their value was deemed equal to the value of the damaged crops. Solomon (peace be upon him), who also heard the judgment, had a different opinion, one that was more accurate and just. Then Prophet Solomon said in the assembly, "It is better that the sheep be handed over to the owner of the crops so that he can benefit from their milk, oil, and wool, while the garden is handed over to the owner of the sheep to cultivate it himself. When the crops have returned to their condition as before they were damaged by the sheep, then the garden should be returned to its owner, and the sheep should also be returned to their owner."

Solomon's opinion was clearly more accurate, because in the end, each of the two parties in the case would get their property back in its entirety.

The difference in perspective between father and son in making a decision on the matter was that David (peace be upon him) focused more on the value of the damage to the crops, which he saw as equal to the value of the sheep that damaged them, so he decided that the sheep should be handed over completely to the owner of the crops. Meanwhile, Solomon (peace be upon him) focused more on the benefits of the sheep and the benefits of the crops, so he made that decision. In any case, each of them based their decision on *ijtihad*, not on revelation, so two different decisions were born.

Furthermore, Prophet David acknowledged that his son's opinion was more accurate, so that is what he later established as his decision, and he revoked his original opinion.

At the end of this verse, Allah explains that He witnessed and knew what David and Solomon had done in examining and deciding the matter, so nothing was hidden from Him.
text.79:
At the beginning of this verse, Allah affirms that He has bestowed upon Sulaiman a higher ability in understanding various matters.

This was indeed proven in the decisions they gave to each party in the case that occurred between the owner of the sheep and the owner of the crops as mentioned above, where the decision given by Sulaiman was felt to be more appropriate and more fulfilling of justice.

After mentioning that, Allah then explains the mercy that He has bestowed upon both of them, namely laws and knowledge, both regarding religion and worldly matters.

Such mercy is also given by Allah to His other prophets, because it is a fundamental requirement to become a Prophet.

Furthermore, in this verse, Allah explains a special favor that He bestowed upon Prophet Daud a.s., namely: that Allah had made the mountains and birds subservient to Daud a.s., all of them glorified Him along with him.

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that He is able to bestow such favors upon His servants, because He is the Creator and Owner of the entire universe.
text.80:
In this verse, Allah mentions another of His favors bestowed upon David (peace be upon him), namely that David was given knowledge and skill in the art of making iron pliable in his hands without heating it. Because of this special ability, David could make armor that people in that era used as self-protection in warfare.

This skill was also utilized by subsequent communities for centuries. Thus, the knowledge and skills that Allah bestowed upon the Prophet David (peace be upon him) have spread widely and benefited people from other nations. In addition to being a miracle of the Prophet David.

Therefore, at the end of this verse, Allah asks the community of the Prophet Muhammad, are they also grateful for this favor? Of course, all those who believe in Him are always grateful for all the blessings He has bestowed.
text.81:
In this verse, Allah begins to mention His specific blessings bestowed upon the Prophet Sulaiman (peace be upon him), namely that He had subjugated the wind for Sulaiman (peace be upon him), so that the wind obediently did what he commanded. For example, the wind would blow in a certain direction, with a strong and fast gust or a gentle and slow one, according to the will of the Prophet Sulaiman (peace be upon him). Allah says:

"Then We subjected to him the wind blowing gently by his command wherever he directed." (Shad/38: 36)

According to the opinion of other scholars, Sulaiman (peace be upon him) used the wind as a means of transportation that carried him from one city to another. Allah says:

"And to Solomon [We subjected] the wind - its morning [journey was that of] a month - and its afternoon [journey was that of] a month." (Saba'/34: 12)

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that He is always aware of everything, so that nothing is hidden from Him.
text.82:
This verse explains another of Allah's blessings bestowed specifically upon the Prophet Solomon (peace be upon him), namely that Allah also subjected a group of devils who obediently carried out what Solomon (peace be upon him) commanded them to do, for example: diving into the sea to retrieve anything he needed, or doing things for Solomon's (peace be upon him) needs such as working on buildings and so on.

In this verse, Allah also affirms that He constantly guarded him so that the devils would not damage or play around in carrying out their tasks.
text.83:
With this verse, Allah reminds His Messenger and the Muslims of the story of Prophet Ayyub (peace be upon him) who was afflicted with a severe illness, so he prayed, seeking help from his Lord to remove his illness, because he was certain that Allah is Most Merciful.

Another opinion from the scholars states that Prophet Ayyub, in this verse, was only pouring out his heart to Allah while glorifying the greatness of Allah, the Most Compassionate and Most Merciful.

Although there are varying narrations obtained about Prophet Ayyub, regarding his personality, his lifetime, and the type of illness he suffered, there are things that can be ascertained about him, namely that he was a righteous servant of Allah, who had received trials from Allah, both regarding his possessions, family, and children, as well as trials that befell himself. And the illness he suffered was severe. Nevertheless, he faced all these trials with patience and reliance (tawakkal) and sought help from Allah, and it did not diminish his faith and worship to Allah in the slightest.
text.84:
Therefore, in this verse, Allah answered his prayer and healed him from the illness, and bestowed upon him more mercy than what had been lost from his hands, and then Allah elevated him to be a prophet.

After Prophet Ayyub recovered from his illness, he lived with his family again, and his family also multiplied abundantly, so that their number became twice the original number.

All of that was Allah's mercy upon him, for his faith, patience, piety, and righteousness. The Qur'an reveals this story to be a warning and a lesson for all who believe and worship Allah, that:

a. Allah grants mercy and help to His believing, pious, righteous, and patient servant.

b. Believers are not exempt from trials, whether heavy or light, as a test for them.

c. A believer must not despair of the mercy of his Lord.

The higher the position and responsibility of a person, the heavier the trials they receive. In this regard, the Messenger of Allah (saw) said:

"Sa'ad bin Abi Waqash asked the Messenger of Allah, "Who are the people with the most severe trials?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "The people with the most severe trials are the prophets, those who resemble the prophets, then those who resemble them." (Narrated by Ibn Majah from Sa'ad bin Abi Waqash)
text.85:
Allah warns the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims with the stories of Prophet Ismail, Idris, and Zulkifli, all of whom were patient in facing the calamities that befell them. Thanks to their patience and piety, Allah bestowed His grace and blessings upon them.

Prophet Ismail (peace be upon him), the son of Prophet Ibrahim from his wife Siti Hajar, proved his patience when his father was about to slaughter him as a sacrifice upon Allah's command. He was also patient and persistent in living in a barren and arid region after his father placed him and his mother in Mecca, in the middle of the arid Arabian Peninsula. Then, he patiently carried out his heavy task of building the Ka'bah and Baitullah (House of Allah) with his father. Therefore, Allah gave high honor and glory to Prophet Ismail, namely by appointing one of his descendants as the last Prophet and Messenger of Allah, namely Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him).

As for Prophet Idris, he was also a pious and patient man. He was sent as a Messenger after Prophet Syis and Prophet Adam (peace be upon them). Many people say that Prophet Idris was the first to be skilled in sewing clothes, and the first to wear sewn clothes, while people before him only wore clothes made of animal skins and were not sewn. In addition, he was also the first to make and use firearms as equipment. The story of Prophet Idris is found in Surah Maryam. (Maryam/19: 56-57)

Regarding Zulkifli, according to the opinion of most commentators of the Quran (mufassirun), he was also a Prophet, and the son of Prophet Ayyub (peace be upon him). Allah sent him as a Prophet after his father. He carried out his da'wah (call to Islam) to monotheism in both creed and worship. Throughout his life, he lived in the land of Sham, and was a pious and patient Prophet. And he was from the Children of Israel (Bani Israil).

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that Prophet Ismail, Idris, and Zulkifli have been included in His mercy, and placed in the Garden of Delight (Jannatuna'im), as a reward for their patience and piety.
text.86:

text.87:
In this verse, Allah reminds His Messenger and all Muslims of the story of Prophet Yunus, who is referred to at the beginning of the verse as "dhun Nun."

*Dhu* means "the possessor of," while *an-Nun* means "the great fish." So, *dhun Nun* means "The Possessor of the Great Fish." He was named so because at one time he was thrown into the sea and swallowed by a large fish. Then, by the grace of Allah, he was able to emerge from the fish's belly safely and intact.

It should be remembered that the story of Prophet Yunus in the Qur'an is found in two surahs, namely Surah al-Anbiya' and Surah Sad. If we compare the verses in these two surahs that contain the story of Prophet Yunus, there are some similarities, for example, in the expressions that read:

"How many a generation have We destroyed before them, and they cried for help when it was no longer the time for escape." (Sad/38:3)

This expression is found in Surah al-Anbiya', and also in the verse of Surah Sad. Also, note al-Anbiya'/21:11 and Yunus/10:13.

In this verse, Allah says, reminding mankind of the story of Prophet Yunus, when he left in anger. What is meant is that at one time Prophet Yunus was very angry with his people because they did not believe in Allah. He had been sent by Allah as His Messenger to convey the call to his people, to invite them to the religion of Allah. But only a few of them believed, while most of them remained disbelieving and disobedient. This situation made him angry, and he went to the seashore, distancing himself from his people.

This story gives the impression that Prophet Yunus could not be patient and tolerant in dealing with his people. But that was indeed the case; he was among the prophets who were narrow-minded. Indeed, of the many Prophets and Messengers sent by Allah, only five are called "Ulul Azmi," namely the messengers who are very patient and persistent. They are Prophet Ibrahim, Musa, Isa, Nuh, and Muhammad (peace be upon them all). While the others, although they are *ma'shum* (protected) from major sins and reprehensible traits, at certain times their hearts also became constricted when facing people who disbelieved and disobeyed Allah.

However, even though Prophet Yunus was angry with his people at one time, his anger was understandable, because he was very sincere towards them, and very eager for them to attain happiness in this world and the hereafter by practicing the religion of Allah that he conveyed to them. But it turned out that most of them remained disbelieving and disobedient. This hurt his heart and ignited his anger.

Even Prophet Muhammad himself, although he was included among the *ulul 'azmi*, Allah repeatedly warned him not to be angry and narrow-minded in dealing with his disbelieving people. Allah says in another verse:

"So be patient, [O Muhammad], for the decision of your Lord, and do not be like the companion of the fish when he called out while he was distressed." (al-Qalam/68:48)

His saying again to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him):

"Then perhaps you would give up some of what is revealed to you, and your breast would be tight therewith..." (Hud/11:12)

In short, the anger found in Prophet Yunus did not arise from a bad trait, but rather from his frustration at seeing the disbelief of his people, whom he had initially hoped would accept and practice the religion of Allah that he conveyed.

Furthermore, in this verse, Allah explains the mistake of Prophet Yunus, where his anger gave the impression that he thought that as a Prophet and Messenger of Allah, he would never be allowed to face difficulties, so that the path he took would always be beautiful without obstacles.

However, in reality, it is not so. In general, the messengers and prophets encounter many obstacles, even torture and ridicule against themselves from disbelievers. Only in very critical situations, whether requested or not by the person concerned, does Allah send His help, so that His Messenger is saved and his disbelieving people experience destruction.

According to a narration quoted from Ibn Kathir, when Prophet Yunus was angry, he distanced himself from his people and went to the seashore. There he found a boat, and he joined it with a gloomy face. When the boat was about to sail, a large wave came, causing the boat to be threatened with sinking if its load was not immediately reduced. So the captain of the boat said, "The sinking of one person is better than the sinking of us all." Then a lottery was held to determine who among them should be removed from the boat. After the lottery, it turned out that Prophet Yunus was the one who had to be removed. However, the passengers of the ship were reluctant to remove him from the boat. So the lottery was held again, but the result remained the same. Even the third lottery was the same. Finally, Yunus took off his clothes and jumped into the sea of his own accord. Allah sent a large fish that swam quickly and swallowed Yunus.

In this verse, Allah further explains that after Prophet Yunus was in three levels of "different darkness," he prayed to Allah, "There is no deity except You; exalted are You. Indeed, I have been of the wrongdoers."

What is meant by three different darknesses here is that Prophet Yunus was in the dark belly of the fish, in the deep and dark sea, and at night which was also pitch black.

Prophet Yunus's confession that he was "among the wrongdoers" means that he was aware of the mistake he had made as a Prophet and Messenger, namely being impatient and intolerant in dealing with his people; he should have been patient until Allah's decree came upon his disbelieving people.

Because of that awareness, he asked forgiveness from Allah, and asked for His help to save himself from that disaster.
text.88:
This verse explains that Allah granted the prayer of Prophet Yunus, and then saved him from immense grief. Grief because of feelings of guilt, grief because of the denial of his people, and grief because of the calamity that befell him.

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that this is how He saves them from worldly torment and bestows upon them the happiness of the hereafter. This is explained by Allah in His word in another verse:

"Then has there never been a [single] city that believed and benefited from its faith except the people of Jonah? When they believed, We removed from them the torment of disgrace in worldly life and allowed them enjoyment for a time." (Yunus/10: 98)

In accordance with the story of Yunus, the Prophet taught his followers who are experiencing difficulties to pray like the prayer of Prophet Yunus. Mus'ab bin Umair narrated from the Messenger of Allah, who said:

"Whoever prays with the prayer of Prophet Yunus, it will be answered." (Riwayat at-Tirmidzi)
text.89:
In this verse, Allah directs the attention of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and his ummah to the story of Prophet Zakaria. Because he had no children, he felt lonely and had no descendants to replace him and continue his struggle after his death. Therefore, he prayed to Allah that He would not let him live without offspring.

At the end of this verse is mentioned the words of Prophet Zakaria after he uttered his prayer. Then he said, "And You are the best of inheritors?" The meaning is that if Allah wills not to grant him offspring, then he is willing and not discouraged, because he is certain that Allah will continue to preserve his religion, and will not neglect his religion, and Allah will certainly choose the most appropriate person to replace Zakaria after his death.

This story has been discussed more extensively in Surah Ali 'Imran and Surah Maryam.
text.90:
This verse explains that Allah had granted the prayer of Prophet Zakaria, and bestowed upon him a son named Yahya. For this, Allah had granted good health to Zakaria's wife, making it possible for her to conceive, even though before that she was a barren woman.

In the continuation of this verse, Allah explains His reason for granting Zakaria's request, which is because they were all always quick to do good deeds, especially in taking care of their offspring in the best possible way. In addition to that, it was also because they always prayed to Allah with hearts that were hopeful and anxious, hopeful for God's forgiveness and anxious about Allah's wrath and punishment. And the third reason is because they were always *khusyuk* and *tawadu'* to Him, and never arrogant or *takabur* and denying His blessings.

So, it is these noble qualities that caused them to obtain blessings from Allah.
text.91:
In this verse, Allah explains the story of Maryam briefly, namely that she was a woman who guarded her chastity. Then, at one point, Allah sent the angel Jibril to inform Maryam that Allah would breathe a spirit into Maryam's body so that she would conceive. Then Maryam gave birth to Isa (peace be upon him) without a father. Because Isa was born without a father, Maryam and Isa then became one of the proofs for the entire universe, regarding the power and oneness of Allah. The birth of Isa contains proof and a sign of Allah's power, just like the case of Prophet Adam who was born into the world without a father and mother, while Isa was born without a father only.

What is astonishing is that Maryam had never had any relationship with men, neither legally through marriage, let alone illegally. Allah mentions Maryam's words about herself as follows:

"No man has ever touched me, nor am I unchaste." (Maryam/19: 20)

Allah's word in another verse;

And Mary, the daughter of Imran, who guarded her chastity. (at-Tahrim/66: 12)

Maryam's astonishment, conveyed to the Angel Jibril, was answered with Allah's word:

He (Jibril) said, "Thus (it will be)." Your Lord says, "That is easy for Me." (Maryam/19: 21)

The signs of Allah's greatness and power shown to Maryam were that she became pregnant without having sexual relations with anyone, and the angels always provided food for her.

Regarding this, the Qur'an narrates Zakaria's question to Maryam and Maryam's answer to him:

"O Maryam! From where did you get this?" She (Maryam) answered, "It is from Allah." (Ali 'Imran/3: 37)

As for the signs of Allah's greatness and omnipotence that are visible through Isa (peace be upon him), they have been explained at length in Surah Ali 'Imran and Surah Maryam.
text.92:
In this verse, it is affirmed that this religion of monotheism is a religion for all of humanity, and it is one religion, that is, the same in creed, even though different in sharia.

The Messenger of Allah said, "We prophets are like brothers from one father, our religion is one." (Narrated by al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Daud and Ahmad from Abu Hurairah.)

Then, at the end of this verse, it is affirmed that Allah is the Lord of all mankind. Therefore, it is to Him alone that they must worship.
text.93:
In this verse, Allah warns the Muslims about the divisions that arise among mankind. All of mankind should adhere to the religion of Tawhid, because the religion revealed by Allah is one, namely the religion of Tawhid (the religion of Islam). However, they have become divided, so that their unity is fragmented into small boxes, strictly separated by differences in views, both regarding non-fundamental issues in religion and purely worldly matters. These differences in understanding are generally accompanied by *taqlid* to an imam or leader, so that one group closes itself off from another. Thus, they have neglected the teachings of religion, which command them to unite and maintain the unity of the *ummah*. But they do the opposite, namely, they become divided.

At the end of this verse, it is emphasized that all of mankind who have become divided will return to Him. Then Allah will perform *hisab* and give recompense for their faith and deeds respectively.
text.94:
In this verse, Allah guarantees that any good deeds performed by a believer, no matter how small, will be rewarded with goodness as well. That good deed will not be lost in vain, and will not be denied because Allah has recorded it for the one who performed it.

Allah's guarantee to give reward for every good deed of His servant is found in His word:

And whoever desires the Hereafter and strives for it with the effort worthy of it while he is a believer - then those are the ones whose endeavor is ever appreciated [by Allah]. (al-Isra'/17: 19)

His word again in another verse:

Indeed, those who have believed and done righteous deeds - indeed, We will not allow to be lost the reward of anyone who does well in deeds. (al-Kahf/18: 30)
text.95:
In this verse, it is explained that it is impossible for the inhabitants of a land that has been destroyed with His punishment not to return to Him.

The meaning is that the people who disbelieve and are infidels, even though they have been destroyed with severe punishment in this world, they will certainly return to Allah in the Hereafter, then all their deeds will be reckoned, and they will be given a fitting reward.
text.96: In this verse, Allah explains that the disbelievers have been destroyed with a severe torment in this world, so that they meet destruction, they will not return to the world again, they will remain in destruction until the Day of Resurrection. As one of the signs of the coming of the Day of Resurrection is the opening of the wall of Gog and Magog (Yakjuj and Makjuj), so that Gog and Magog (Yakjuj and Makjuj) come, sliding swiftly from every high place. They create chaos and destruction in the world.
text.97:
In this verse, it is emphasized that at the time of the emergence of Gog and Magog (Ya'juj and Ma'juj), and when the coming of the true promise, namely the Day of Resurrection and Reckoning (hisab), is near, the eyes of the disbelievers will suddenly widen in shock. They will cry out in regret, "Woe to us! Indeed, we were heedless of the coming of the Day of Resurrection and Reckoning, so we did not prepare ourselves well. Indeed, we were wrongdoers to ourselves and to others, because we were warned that the Day of Resurrection and Reckoning would surely come, but we did not heed the warning, and even denied it."

However, no matter how much they regret it at that time, the regret will be of no use, because the Day of Resurrection and Reckoning has indeed come, while they did not believe in it at all.
text.98:
This verse affirms to the polytheists of Mecca that they, along with what they worship besides Allah, for as long as they live in this world, such as idols, animals, inanimate objects, trees, or sacred places and so on, will be entered into Hellfire. This is a promise from Allah to them, which He will surely fulfill.

In this verse, it is mentioned that the polytheists along with their objects of worship will be entered into Hellfire, even though those who are sinful and associate partners with God in this matter are the worshippers. As for the objects of worship, they know nothing about what their worshippers do. The wisdom of including the objects of worship along with their worshippers is to show them that their belief in those objects of worship during their life in the world was incorrect. They used to believe that the idols and everything they worshipped would intercede for them on the Day of Judgment, so that they would be spared from Allah's punishment. Through the intercession of these objects of worship, they would be admitted into Paradise. After the Day of Judgment comes and after they enter Hell together with the objects of worship they worshipped, it becomes clear that those objects of worship cannot do anything for them. Thus, the error of the belief they held is proven, and the truth of the message that Muhammad once conveyed to them is confirmed.
text.99: This verse explains that if the deities worshipped by the polytheists were truly gods besides Allah, as they believe, then surely those deities would be saved along with them. Because if they were gods, they would be all-powerful and mighty, and nothing could punish them; indeed, they themselves would punish those who disobeyed them. However, what happens is that all of them, both the idol worshippers and the idols they worship, will abide eternally in Hell.
text.100:
Then Allah explains the condition of the idol worshippers and their idols in hell, namely:

1. They in hell groan and lament, and their breath becomes constricted, bearing an indescribably terrible torment.

As for those who are wretched, they will be in the Fire, wherein they will exhale and inhale with moaning. (Hud/11:106)

2. The idol worshippers who are being punished are unable to know the condition of their other companions who are also being punished, because they do not have time to think about it; each of them is busy facing the torment that constantly befalls them.
text.101:
This verse explains the state of those who believe and do righteous deeds, and those whom Allah has granted the ability to obey Him, that they will not be put into Hell, nor will they even be brought near to it.

It is narrated by al-Hakim from Ibn Abbas that when verse 98 was revealed, the polytheists of Quraysh felt stricken by it. They said, "Muhammad has insulted our gods." Then they went to Ibn az-Ziba'ra and told him about the verse that had been revealed. He replied, "If I were to confront Muhammad, I would surely be able to refute him." The polytheists of Quraysh said, "What would you say?" He replied, "I would say to him, 'Al-Masih (the Messiah) is worshipped by the Christians, 'Uzair (Ezra) is worshipped by the Jews, will Al-Masih and 'Uzair be fuel for the fire of Hell?'" The hearts of the Quraysh were drawn to the words of Ibn az-Ziba'ra and they felt they had defeated Muhammad. Then verses 99 to 101 of this Surah were revealed, which affirmed verse 98 above.

With the revelation of these verses, Ibn az-Ziba'ra was silenced and the hearts of the polytheists were once again in doubt. But because of their envy towards the Prophet Muhammad and the Muslims, they remained in their polytheism.
text.102:
Allah explains the state of the inhabitants of Paradise, namely:

1. They will not hear the sound of the fire of Hell caused by its flames and the sound of burning things being consumed.

2. They will be in continuous pleasure and joy, enjoying everything they desire, hearing everything that pleases their hearts, and seeing what delights their eyes.

3. They will not be distressed by the sound of the last trumpet, which is the sound of the trumpet signaling the resurrection of mankind from the graves to be reckoned. Allah says:

And the Horn will be blown, and whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth will fall dead except whom Allah wills. Then it will be blown again, and at once they will be standing, looking on. (az-Zumar/39: 68)

4. They will be greeted by the angels conveying glad tidings of their victory. As if the angels are saying to them, "This is the Day that Allah promised you, O believers, when you were in the world. At this time, Allah bestows great rewards and eternal pleasure as a reward for your faith, obedience, and purity from sin by performing righteous deeds and by carrying out all of Allah's commands and avoiding all that He has forbidden."
text.103:
Allah explains the state of the inhabitants of Paradise, namely:

1. They will not hear the sound of the fire of Hell caused by its flames and the sound of burning things being consumed.

2. They will be in continuous pleasure and joy, enjoying everything they desire, hearing everything that pleases their hearts, and seeing what delights their eyes.

3. They will not be distressed by the sound of the last trumpet, which is the sound of the trumpet signaling the resurrection of mankind from the graves to be reckoned. Allah says:

And the Horn will be blown, and whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth will fall dead except whom Allah wills. Then it will be blown again, and at once they will be standing, looking on. (az-Zumar/39: 68)

4. They will be greeted by the angels conveying glad tidings of their victory. As if the angels are saying to them, "This is the Day that Allah promised you, O believers, when you were in the world. At this time, Allah bestows great rewards and eternal pleasure as a reward for your faith, obedience, and purity from sin by performing righteous deeds and by carrying out all of Allah's commands and avoiding all that He has forbidden."
text.104:
Those who are greeted by the angels do not feel fear or shock at the coming of the Day of Judgment, when the heavens are folded and replaced with other heavens, as if the old heavens are folded away for storage and the new heavens are unfolded. Allah says:

And they have not appraised Allah with true appraisal, while the earth entirely will be [within] His grip on the Day of Resurrection, and the heavens will be folded in His right hand. Exalted is He and high above what they associate with Him. (az-Zumar/39: 67)

Thus, Allah resurrects mankind after they die and are in their graves, to be gathered in the gathering place (padang mahsyar), so that their deeds can be reckoned. Resurrecting mankind after death and disintegration into dust is easy for Allah. If Allah created mankind from nothing into existence, then repeating their creation is certainly easier than creating them the first time. Resurrecting mankind again for reckoning is a promise from Allah that will surely be fulfilled.

Scientifically, as explained in verse 30 of this surah, the creation of the universe began from nothingness (a state of singularity: infinitely large mass, infinitely small volume) which then exploded violently and then formed the universe which continues to expand to this day. Evidence of this expanding universe can be found in observations with telescopes which show that over time, the distance between celestial objects is increasing. Scientists say that the universe will continue to expand until the critical mass of the universe is reached. When this critical mass has been reached, the attractive force (gravity) between the mass of various celestial objects will restrain the process of the universe's expansion.

It will even reach a state of contraction of the universe. The universe, which was initially expanding, will shrink (contract) and one day will be destroyed and return to its initial state (singularity); this state is what is called the Day of Judgment (hari kiamat). The Day of Judgment in this verse is described as the day when Allah will "roll up the heavens," like rolling up sheets of paper, just like the first creation. The term "rolling up the heavens" is an appropriate expression, because in reality the universe is not round but flat, consisting of trillions of galaxies that form a "roll."
text.105:
This verse explains that Allah has sent down books to the Messengers, such as the Torah, Zabur, Gospel, and Al-Qur'an. In these books, it is explained that the earth belongs to Allah, inherited by whomever He wills. Allah has also decreed in this verse that the servants who inherit the earth are those who are able to cultivate and prosper the earth, as long as they follow Allah's guidance.

If we observe world history and the history of mankind, those whom Allah has made rulers on this earth are those who are able to manage and lead society, cultivate this earth for the benefit of mankind, are able to defend themselves from external attacks, and can strengthen the unity of the people in their country. The granting of power by Allah to these people does not mean that Allah has approved of their actions; because worldly life is different from the life of the hereafter. Some are happy living only in the hereafter, and some are happy living only in this world. While what a Muslim aspires to is to be happy in this world and in the hereafter.

If Muslims want to live happily in this world and the hereafter, they must follow the Sunnatullah above, namely to obediently worship Allah, be able to lead mankind well, be able to cultivate this earth for the benefit of mankind, and build strong unity and solidarity among themselves so that they are not easily divided by enemies.

The mufassir (interpreters of the Quran) differ in their interpretation of the word "earth" in this verse, including:

a. Some experts of tafsir interpret "earth" in this verse as "heaven". Because "heaven" is inherited by Allah to His servants who believe and do good deeds. Allah says:

"And they will say, "Praise to Allah, who has fulfilled His promise to us and made us inherit the earth [of Paradise] to settle wherever we will therein. And excellent is the reward of [righteous] workers." (az-Zumar/39: 74)

b. Others interpret the word "earth" as the earth that is now inhabited by mankind. Allah says:

"Allah has promised those who have believed among you and done righteous deeds that He will surely grant them succession [to authority] upon the earth." (an-Nur/24: 55)

"Indeed, the earth belongs to Allah. He gives it as inheritance to whom He wills of His servants. And the [best] outcome is for the righteous." (al-A'raf/7: 128)

c. Some other mufassir interpret "earth" as the holy land inherited by the righteous, Allah says:

"And We caused the people who had been oppressed to inherit the eastern regions of the land and the western ones, which We had blessed." (al-A'raf/7: 137)
text.106:
Allah clarifies that all the stories explained in this surah are lessons and reminders conveyed from the beginning to the end of the surah. They are sufficient as lessons and contain many wisdoms, serving as provisions and materials for those who wish to achieve happiness in this world and the hereafter. Indeed, the verses in this surah are stern warnings and threats from Allah to those who deny the calls of the messengers. They will be afflicted by great calamities, as has befallen previous nations.

Therefore, Muslims are obligated to take lessons and practice these verses so as not to be affected by Allah's threat in the form of a very terrible punishment and calamity.
text.107:
The purpose of Allah sending Prophet Muhammad, bringing His religion, is none other than to provide guidance and warnings so that they may be happy in this world and the hereafter. Allah's mercy for the entire universe encompasses protection, peace, compassion, and so on, which Allah bestows upon His creation. This includes those who believe and those who do not, including animals and plants.

If we look at the history of mankind and humanity, then the religion of Islam is a religion that strives with all its might to abolish slavery and oppression by humans against other humans. If the door to slavery is still open, it is only to reciprocate the actions of the disbelievers against the Muslims. Meanwhile, avenues for abolishing slavery are provided, both by giving large rewards to those who free slaves and by linking *kaffarat*/atonement with the freeing of slaves. Improvements regarding the status of women, who at that time were almost equal to animals, and recognition of the status of orphans, attention to the poor and needy, the command to perform jihad to fight ignorance and poverty, all are taught by the Al-Qur'an and Hadith. Thus, all of humanity receives mercy, whether directly or indirectly, from the religion brought by Prophet Muhammad. But most people still deny it, even though the mercy they receive is the mercy and blessings of Allah.
text.108: Allah commands Muhammad to convey to the disbelievers and to those to whom the call has reached, that the essence of the revelation conveyed to him is that there is no god worthy of worship except Allah. Therefore, let mankind worship Him, and never associate anything with Him, such as acknowledging the existence of other gods besides Him, or believing that anything besides Allah possesses supernatural power like the power of Allah. And surrender yourself to Allah by purifying obedience and submission only to Him, and follow all the revelations that were revealed to the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him).
text.109:
Then Allah reminds Muhammad of his duty as a Messenger, which is only to convey Allah's religion to mankind. Therefore, if they do not heed your call, do not follow the revelation conveyed to them, then do not grieve, and say to them that you have shown them the straight path, leading to perfect happiness. If they do not want to follow and take the path that has been laid out, it means they want to receive punishment from Allah.

In another verse, Allah says:

And if they (still) deny you (Muhammad), then say, "For me is my deed, and for you is your deed. You are disassociated from what I do, and I am disassociated from what you do." (Yunus/10: 41)

If the disbelievers ask you, Muhammad, about when the promised punishment will be inflicted, then say to them that you do not know anything about the time, when the punishment will be inflicted, because the full authority is in the hands of Allah, and no one knows it.
text.110: Allah is All-Knowing of everything said by the disbelievers about the Islamic religion, whether said openly or whispered, and Allah knows the hatred in the hearts of the disbelievers towards the Muslims. Therefore, He will give a fitting recompense to those who are like that.
text.111: Allah also commanded Muhammad to inform the disbelievers that he did not know in the slightest why the punishment was delayed in coming. It may be so that they can enjoy all worldly pleasures until the time appointed by Allah, then Allah will inflict punishment suddenly without them knowing from where it comes.
text.112:
Because the polytheists of Mecca were increasing in their oppression day by day, Muhammad prayed to God that He would hasten to inflict punishment upon them. Muhammad's request was granted by Allah with the defeat of the polytheists in several battles that occurred between the Muslims and the polytheists.

Qatadah said, "The prophets of old used to pray":

"Our Lord, decide between us and our people with truth, and You are the best of deciders." (al-A'raf/7: 89)

So the Messenger of Allah (saw) was commanded by Allah to utter such a prayer.
